description: A short lesson to help you apply The Caesar Cipher: Rome's Secret Messages.

hook.text: Julius Caesar sent military orders that enemies couldn't read â€” by shifting every letter three places.

buildup.text: The Caesar cipher replaces each letter with one a fixed number of positions down the alphabet.

discovery.text: A becomes D, B becomes E, C becomes F. Simple, but effective when your enemies can't read at all.

twist.text: With only 25 possible shifts, you can break it by trying every one. Today it's a children's puzzle.

climax.text: The Caesar cipher introduced substitution â€” the idea that powers all modern encryption.

punchline.text: The first encryption was just counting to three.

quiz.question: How does a Caesar cipher work?
options: Shifting each letter by a fixed number of positions
